lessonOverview.title: Unit 4 - Lesson 2
structures: B: Yes, they are. / No, they aren’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six more jobs (singers, dancers, farmers, vets, firefighters, police officers) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use SB visuals to introduce plural job names (e.g., farmers, dancers). Say the word, students repeat and identify them in a group scene.
stretchStrategies: Picture Swap Challenge – In pairs, students describe a picture without showing it, using “They’re...” / “They aren’t...” to help their partner guess which one it is. Encourage added detail: They’re dancers. They’re wearing pink dresses.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about people’s jobs using “They’re...” / “They aren’t...” and ask and answer simple questions using “Are they...?” and “Yes, they are.” / “No, they aren’t.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Ask: “Are they singers?” Show a picture. Students respond with “Yes, they are.” or “No, they aren’t.” Drill with partner pairs.
stretchStrategies: Picture Swap Challenge – In pairs, students describe a picture without showing it, using “They’re...” / “They aren’t...” to help their partner guess which one it is. Encourage added detail: They’re dancers. They’re wearing pink dresses.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “They’re ___.” / “They aren’t ___.” and ask and answer using “Are they ___?” / “Yes, they are.” / “No, they aren’t.” to talk about people’s jobs.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write: “They’re ___.” / “They aren’t ___.” + “Are they ___?” on the board. Students practise with job flashcards in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Picture Swap Challenge – In pairs, students describe a picture without showing it, using “They’re...” / “They aren’t...” to help their partner guess which one it is. Encourage added detail: They’re dancers. They’re wearing pink dresses.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
